docs.title: DynareJulia User Guide
docs.text: Welcome to DynareJulia User Guide. This guide is designed to help users get started, understand the workflow, and fully leverage the capabilities of DynareJulia.

docs.title: What is DynareJulia?
docs.text:
DynareJulia is a high-performance, modern, and flexible framework for solving, simulating, and analyzing dynamic economic models — written in Julia, and inspired by the powerful features of Dynare and the computational speed of Julia.

It is especially useful for researchers, economists, and policy analysts who need to:

  • Solve DSGE, OLG, and other structural models
  • Run simulations and perform sensitivity analysis
  • Customize model components using Julia's extensive scientific ecosystem

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• 🔗 Main GitHub Repository: DynareJulia/Dynare.jl Browse the codebase, contribute, or report issues.

  • 📘 Official Documentation: DynareJulia Documentation Explore API details, examples, and model syntax.

(For installation instructions, visit the Installation page.)

Use the navigation bar to explore topics such as:

  • ❓ FAQ

Happy modeling!

docs.title: Getting Started with DynareJulia
docs.text: This section will walk you through installing Julia — the foundational language for running DynareJulia.

docs.title: Step 1: Download Julia
docs.text:
DynareJulia currently requires Julia version 1.9.4 for compatibility and performance reasons.

🛠️ You must install version 1.9.4, not the latest version.

To download it:

👉 Visit the Julia Old Releases Page

Then scroll down to find: Version 1.9.4 (released on 2023-12-21)

Select the appropriate installer based on your operating system:

docs.title: 💻 For Windows
docs.text:
• Click on: julia-1.9.4-win64.exe (or julia-1.9.4-win32.exe if using 32-bit)
  • Run the installer
  • Accept default settings (you can check “Add Julia to PATH” if available)

docs.title: 🍎 For macOS
docs.text:
• Click on: julia-1.9.4-mac64.dmg
  • Open the .dmg file and drag Julia into your Applications folder

docs.title: 🐧 For Linux
docs.text:
• Download the julia-1.9.4-linux-x86_64.tar.gz
  • Extract it using your terminal

docs.title: Step 2: Testing
docs.text:
Step 3: Install Visual Studio Code (VS Code)

Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is a lightweight and powerful code editor. We recommend it for writing and managing Julia code, editing .mod model files, and building this documentation.

docs.title: 📥 Download VS Code
docs.text:
1. Go to the official VS Code download page
  2. Choose your operating system:
  3. Windows: Click on the .exe installer
  4. macOS: Choose the .zip or .dmg version
  5. Linux: Download the .deb or .rpm file

docs.title: 💻 Windows
docs.text:
• Run the downloaded .exe file
  • During setup:
  • ✅ Enable “Add to PATH”
  • ✅ Enable “Open with Code” in the right-click context menu
  • Complete the installation by clicking Next through the installer

docs.title: 🍎 macOS
docs.text:
• Open the downloaded .dmg file
  • Drag the Visual Studio Code icon into your Applications folder
  • Open VS Code from the Applications menu or using Spotlight (Cmd + Space, then type "Code")

docs.title: Step 4: Install the Julia Extension in VS Code
docs.text: To enable full Julia support in VS Code — including syntax highlighting, interactive REPL, inline plots, variable browser, and more — you need to install the official Julia extension.

docs.title: 4.1 How to Install the Julia Extension
docs.text:
1. Open Visual Studio Code
  2. Click on the Extensions icon in the left sidebar (or press Ctrl+Shift+X)

  3. In the search bar at the top, type: Julia

  4. Look for the extension published by Julia Language — it should appear first in the list

  5. Name: Julia

  6. Publisher: Julia Language

  7. Click the Install button

docs.title: 4.2 First-Time Setup
docs.text:
After installing the extension:

  1. Open a Julia file, or click View → Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P)
  2. Type: Execute Active File
  3. VS Code will prompt you to select the Julia executable path (if it doesn't auto-detect it)

  4. Browse to the path where Julia 1.9.4 is installed:

  5. On Windows (default):

C:\Users\<YourUsername>\AppData\Local\Programs\Julia-1.9.4\bin\julia.exe

  • On macOS:

/Applications/Julia-1.9.app/Contents/Resources/julia/bin/julia

  • On Linux (if installed via tarball):

/opt/julia-1.9.4/bin/julia

  1. Select the correct path → the extension will configure automatically

docs.title: ✅ Verify Julia REPL Integration
docs.text:
To check if it's working:

  1. Create a new file and save it as test.jl
  2. Add:

println("Hello from Julia in VS Code!")

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This section explains how to install the necessary components to use DynareJulia, starting with setting up a Python virtual environment and preparing to install Dynare.

docs.title: Step 1: Set Up a Virtual Environment
docs.text: Before installing Dynare, it's recommended to create a virtual environment (venv) inside the folder where your model files will be stored.

docs.title: What is a Virtual Environment?
docs.text:
A virtual environment is an isolated workspace that keeps your project's dependencies (such as Python packages or Dynare wrappers) separate from your system-wide configuration.

Using a venv helps: - Keep each modeling project self-contained - Avoid conflicts with other tools or versions - Improve reproducibility when sharing your setup

docs.title: 1.1 Create a project folder
docs.text: Create a directory where your .mod files and Julia scripts will live: activate venv

docs.title: Step 2: Install Dynare in Julia
docs.text: Once your virtual environment is ready and Julia is installed, the next step is to install the Dynare.jl package using Julia’s package manager.

docs.title: 2.1 Open the Julia REPL
docs.text: There are two ways to launch the Julia REPL:

docs.title: Option A: From your system terminal
docs.text:
Simply type:

 ```bash julia ```

docs.title: Option B: From inside Visual Studio Code
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + Shift + P (or Cmd + Shift + P on macOS)
  2. In the Command Palette, type:
  3. Press Enter VS Code will open a terminal panel with the Julia REPL running.

docs.title: 2.2 Add the Dynare.jl package
docs.text:
Once the REPL is open, enter the following commands:

```julia using Pkg Pkg.add("Dynare")

docs.title: 2.3 First-Time Use
docs.text:
After installing Dynare.jl, test that the package loads correctly.

In the Julia REPL, type:

using Dynare

Note: The first time you use the package, Julia will precompile it. This may take a minute.

Recommendation: After installing packages, it is good practice to restart your Julia REPL or VS Code terminal. This ensures that all changes take effect properly, especially when adding new packages or changing environments.

docs.title: 2.4 Optional: Check the Installed Version
docs.text:
To verify which version of Dynare was installed, run:

Pkg.status("Dynare")

You should see an output like:

Dynare v0.9.18

This confirms the package is installed and active in your Julia environment.
